message.content: This question requires knowledge about the formation and movements of planets in our solar system. Planets orbit around a burning hydrogen ball, also known as a star, which is the Sun in our solar system. Option (A) is incorrect because asteroids are smaller celestial objects that can orbit around the Sun but are not the primary body that planets orbit. Option (B) is incorrect because moons are natural satellites that orbit around planets, not the other way around. Option (D) is incorrect because planets do have an orbit around a central star.

This question requires basic knowledge about the solar system and the way planets move. Planets orbit around a burning hydrogen ball, which is commonly known as a star or the sun. Option (A) is incorrect because asteroids are small rocky objects that can orbit the sun, but they do not have enough mass to be the main object of planetary orbits. Option (B) is incorrect because while moons do orbit around planets, planets do not orbit around moons. Option (D) is incorrect because planets do have orbits around a central object.

This question requires basic knowledge about astronomy and the solar system. Planets orbit around a burning hydrogen ball, which refers to the sun. The sun is a star made primarily of hydrogen gas, which undergoes nuclear fusion to produce energy. Option (A) is incorrect because asteroids are small rocky or metallic objects that orbit the sun, like planets do. Option (B) is incorrect because moons are natural satellites that orbit planets, not the other way around. Option (D) is incorrect because all planets in our solar system have orbits around the sun.

This question requires a basic understanding of the solar system and celestial bodies. Planets orbit around a burning hydrogen ball, referring to the Sun. The Sun is a star composed mainly of hydrogen that undergoes nuclear fusion, producing heat and light. Option (A) is incorrect because asteroids are smaller rocky objects that can orbit around the Sun, but planets do not orbit around them. Option (B) is also incorrect because while moons orbit around planets, planets themselves do not orbit around moons. Option (D) is not true because all planets in our solar system do have orbits around the Sun.

Option (B) is incorrect because moons are natural satellites that orbit around planets, not the other way around. Option (D) is incorrect because planets do have orbits.
